<math alttext="open bracket, Z n, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 4, close bracket, with a negative 2 charge plus 2 electrons produce Z n plus 4 O H with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>[Zn(OH)</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>4</mn> </mrow> </msub> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>]</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <msup> <mrow> <mi>e</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mo>→</mo> <mtext>Zn</mtext> <mo>+</mo> <mn>4</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>OH</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>
 <math alttext="negative 1.20" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1.20</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="Z n, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, plus 2 electrons produce Z n plus 2 O H with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mrow> <mtext>ZnO</mtext> <msub> <mrow> <mo>+</mo> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mtext>O</mtext> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext> </mtext> <msup> <mrow> <mi>e</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mo>→</mo> <mtext>Zn</mtext> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>OH</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>
 <math alttext="negative 1.25" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1.25</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="H g O plus H 2 O plus 2 electrons react to produce H g plus 2 O H with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mrow> <mtext>HgO</mtext> <mo>+</mo> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mtext>O</mtext> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <msup> <mrow> <mi>e</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mo>→</mo> <mtext>Hg</mtext> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>OH</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>
 <math alttext="positive 0.10" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="O 2 plus 2 H 2 O plus 4 electrons react to produce 4 O H with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>O</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mtext>O</mtext> <mo>+</mo> <mn>4</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <msup> <mrow> <mi>e</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mo>→</mo> <mn>4</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>OH</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>
 <math alttext="positive 0.40" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

Pacemakers are electronic devices that help regulate the heart rate. Currently, lithium-iodine cells are commonly used to power pacemakers and have replaced zinc-mercury cells. Table 1 provides the overall equation and operating cell potential, <math alttext="E" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for each cell. Table 2 provides the standard reduction potentials for several half-reactions related to zinc-mercury and zinc-air cells.
content.question: The use of zinc-mercury cells in hearing aids has been replaced by zinc-air cells that operate using the oxidation of <math alttext="Z n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> by <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> from the air, generating a potential of <math alttext="positive 1.60 volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1.60</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Table 2 provides the standard reduction potentials for the half-reactions used in zinc-mercury and zinc-air cells. Which of the following best explains the modification to the cell design that is mostly responsible for the difference in standard cell potentials for zinc-mercury and zinc-air cells?

choices.label: The greater standard cell potential of the <math alttext="Z n air" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn-air</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cell compared to that of the zinc-mercury cell most likely results from the thermodynamically more favorable reduction of <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> compared to <math alttext="H g O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HgO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The greater standard cell potential of the <math alttext="Z n air" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn-air</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cell compared to that of the zinc-mercury cell most likely results from the greater number of moles of <math alttext="electrons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> required to reduce <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> compared to <math alttext="H g O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HgO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The greater standard cell potential of the <math alttext="Z n air" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn-air</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cell compared to that of the zinc-mercury cell most likely results from the thermodynamically less favorable reduction of <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> compared to <math alttext="H g O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HgO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The greater standard cell potential of the <math alttext="Z n air" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn-air</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cell compared to that of the zinc-mercury cell most likely results from the greater number of moles of hydroxide ions required to reduce <math alttext="open bracket, Z n, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 4, close bracket, with a negative 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[Zn(OH)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> compared to <math alttext="Z n, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Zn(OH)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The greater standard cell potential of the <math alttext="Z n air" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn-air</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cell compared to that of the zinc-mercury cell most likely results from the thermodynamically more favorable reduction of <math alttext="O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> compared to <math alttext="H g O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HgO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
